case_name: L. Hazarimal Kuthiala v. Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala

facts.text: The appellant firm is L. Hazarimal Kuthiala of Kapurthala.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant firm, L. Hazarimal Kuthiala of Kapurthala, moved the high Court of Punjab under article 226 of the Constitution for writs of

facts.text: Appellant firm moved the High Court of Punjab under article 226 for writs against Income-tax Officer Special Circle Ambala and Commissioner of Income-tax Punjab for reassessment of income for account year 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant firm, L. Hazarimal Kuthiala of Kapurthala, moved the high Court of Punjab under article 226 of the Constitution for writs of prohibition, certiorari, quo warranto, etc., against the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, and the Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab  1 , Himachal Pradesh, Bilaspur and Simla, in respect of reassessment of the income of the firm for the account year, 1945-46.

facts.text: High Court dismissed the petition but granted certificate under Arts 132 and 133, appeal filed on that certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the petition, but granted a certificate under Arts. 132 and 133 of the Constitution, and this appeal has been filed on that certificate.

facts.text: Firm carried on business as forest lessees and timber merchants at Dhilwan in former Kapurthala State.

anchor.surface_text: The firm carried on business as forest lessees and timber merchants at Dhilwan in the former Kapurthala State.

facts.text: Income-tax law was in force in Kapurthala State.

anchor.surface_text: In that State, an income-tax law was in force, and prior to the integration of the State, on April 10, 1947, the income of the firm for the account year 1945-1946  Samvat 2002  was duly assessed, and the tax was also paid.

facts.text: Prior to integration on April 10, 1947, income of firm for account year 1945-46 Samvat 2002 was assessed and tax paid in Kapurthala State.

anchor.surface_text: and prior to the integration of the State, on April 10, 1947, the income of the firm for the account year 1945-1946  Samvat 2002  was duly assessed, and the tax was also paid.

facts.text: Kapurthala integrated into Pepsu.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently political quahogs took place, Kapurthala integrated into what was known as Pepsu,

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued two Ordinances in Samvat 2005 ceasing Kapurthala laws including income-tax law from August 20, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and the Rajpramukh issued two Ordinances in Samvat 2005, by which all laws in force in Kapurthala including the income-tax law ceased to be operative from August 20, 1948.

facts.text: Ordinances applied Patiala Income-tax Act 2001 to the area.

anchor.surface_text: The two Ordinances instead applied laws in force in the Patiala State to the area of the new State which included Kapurthala, and the Patiala Income-tax Act, 2001, came into force.

facts.text: Indian Finance Act 1950 applied Indian Income-tax Act to Part B States.

anchor.surface_text: Later still, the Indian Finance Act, 1950  26 of 1950 , applied the Indian Income-tax Act to the Part B States, which had emerged as a result of political changes.

facts.text: Section 13 of Indian Finance Act 1950 repealed income-tax laws in Part B States except for levy assessment collection for defined period.

anchor.surface_text: Section 13 of the Indian Finance Act, 1950, repealed the income-tax laws obtaining in the area of the Part B States except for the purposes of levy, assessment and companylection of income-tax and super-tax in respect of the period defined therein.

facts.text: On March 12, 1955, Income-tax Officer Special Circle Ambala issued notice under section 34 of Patiala Income-tax Act Samvat 2001 to appellant firm to file return as income under-assessed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 12, 1955, the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, issued a numberice purporting to be under section 34 of the Patiala Income-tax Act of Samvat 2001 to the appellant firm calling upon it to file a return of its income and total world income, because he had reason to believe that the income had been under-assessed

facts.text: On November 4, 1953, Commissioner of Income-tax ordered that assessment of appellant firm be done by ITO Special Circle Ambala not by ITO B-Ward Patiala under section 5(5) and 7A of Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: previous to this, on November 4, 1953, the Commissioner of Income-tax Act, Punjab  1 , Himachal Pradesh, Bilaspur and Simla, purporting to act under section 5, sub-sections  5  and  7A , of the Indian Income-tax Act, ordered that the assessment of the appellant firm would be done by the Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Ambala, and number by the Income-tax Officer, B-Ward, Patiala, who ordinarily would be the companypetent authority under section 64 of the Indian Income-tax Act to assess the appellant firm.

facts.text: ITO B-Ward Patiala ordinarily competent authority under section 64 Indian Income-tax Act to assess appellant firm.

anchor.surface_text: who ordinarily would be the companypetent authority under section 64 of the Indian Income-tax Act to assess the appellant firm.

facts.text: Appellant firm raised objections but failed and filed petition under Art 226.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant firm raised objections, but failed, and then filed the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, out of which the present appeal arises.

facts.text: Argument under article 14 abandoned.

anchor.surface_text: An argument under article 14 of the Constitution has number been abandoned, though it figured at earlier stages of the present case.

facts.text: Reassessment cannot be made under Patiala Income-tax Act not in dispute, respondents state it would be under Kapurthala law Samvat 2002.

anchor.surface_text: A second point that the reassessment cannot be made under the Patiala Income-tax Act is number in dispute, because the respondents before us states that the reassessment, if any, would have to be done in accordance with the Kapurthala law, as it existed in the assessment year  Samvat 2002 .

facts.text: Argument that section 13 Indian Finance Act 1950 did not include reassessment abandoned.

facts.text: Only point pressed: ITO Special Circle Ambala had no jurisdiction to issue notice under section 34, only ITO B-Ward Patiala competent.

holdings.text: The exercise of a power will be referable to jurisdiction which confers validity upon it and not to a jurisdiction under which it will be nugatory

anchor.surface_text: This argument, however, loses point, because the exercise of a power will be referable to jurisdiction which confers validity upon it and not to a jurisdiction under which it will be nugatory. holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle from Pitamber Vajirshet; order under Indian Act referable to Patiala Act for validity in reassessment context

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failure to consult does not invalidate as directory per precedents; public duty where nullity causes inconvenience without promoting legislative object (Normandin principle)

holdings.text: harmonious construction thus requires that the two sub-sections must be taken to cover different situations
holdings.reasoning_summary: s5(7A) limited to pending cases per Bidi Supply; s5(5) covers non-pending to avoid gap; no otioseness

holdings.text: nothing much turns upon the employment of the plural number, because the plural includes the singular. Indeed, a single case might well be in a class separate from others
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: plural 'persons or classes' includes singular individual; single case as distinct class

holdings.text: Duplication of powers is sometimes noticeable in statutes, and does not destroy the effectiveness of the powers conferred. Section 24 of the Civil Procedure Code dealing with transfers of cases and the provisions of the Letters Patent of the High Court are instances in point
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory duplication valid (CPC s24, Letters Patent examples); action valid under one provision not invalidated by another

holdings.text: the order of the Commissioner was valid, because he arranged and distributed work, and did not seek to transfer any case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order under s5(5) validly assigns non-pending case as distribution of work to specific ITO

precedents.case_name: K S Srinivasan v Union of India

precedents.citation: Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin L.R. 1917 A.C. 170

anchor.surface_text: This Court relied upon the decision of the Privy Council in Montreal Street Railway Company v. Normandin  L.R. 1917 A.C. 170 , where it was observed as follows The question whether provisions in a statute are directory or imperative has very frequently arisen in this companyntry, but it has been said that numbergeneral rule can be laid down, and that in every case the object of the statute must be looked at.

precedents.case_name: Montreal Street Railway Company v Normandin
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions relating to performance of public duty are directory if holding them mandatory would cause serious inconvenience without promoting legislative object
precedents.cited_holding: When the provisions of a statute relate to the performance of a public duty and the case is such that to hold null and void acts done in neglect of this duty would work serious general inconvenience... it has been the practice to hold such provisions to be directory only

precedents.citation: Biswanath Khemka v. King Emperor 1945 F.C.R. 99

anchor.surface_text: The principal of the Privy Council case was also applied by the Federal Court in Biswanath Khemka v. King Emperor  1945 F.C.R. 99 , and there, as pointed out by this companyrt, the words of the provision were even more emphatic and of a prohibitory character. The presence of the rule is that where companysultation has to be made during the performance of a public duty and an omission to do so occurs, the action cannot be regarded as altogether void, and the direction for companysultation may be treated as directory and its neglect, as of numberconsequence to the result.

precedents.cited_proposition: Consultation provisions are directory even if emphatic or prohibitory
